threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
One of the things that really gets me when it comes to online witchcraft and magic spaces is how hard people push the narrative that beginner magic is dangerous. It really isn't. No demon is going to show up and suck out your soul because you accidentally summoned it. No deity is going to go out of their way to harm you. Most spirits can be dealt with using a basic banishing spell. It is extremely uncommon for witches to hex each other, but you wouldn't guess it from the fear mongering that goes around about it.

What IS important for beginner witches is learning mundane skills like discernment and critical thinking. Because when you're just getting started, the most dangerous thing you are going to encounter is other practitioners preying on newbies. Know how to spot grooming. Know how to spot cult-like behavior. Know how to read books critically. Know how to spot bullshit when you see it.

Have fun with beginner magic. Get messy. Make mistakes. Fuck around and find out. There's no need to be afraid of it. No one ever cultivated a craft or skill by being too afraid to DO.

>The Buddha didn’t answer those questions because they’re irrelevant to the path of liberation, which heals the mind. For example, if a man has been wounded by an arrow and is in agony, to end that pain he needs to have the arrow removed and the wound treated. The wound isn’t healed and the pain is not stopped by finding out the name of the person who fired the arrow, whether he was fair or dark, tall or short, what town or village he lives in, the size of the bow that fired the arrow, and so on.

>Nāgārjuna said that the questions the Buddha did not answer were based on the view that phenomena have self-existing natures. threads.sub: Question for those who believe in human souls
threads.com:
If there is an immaterial human soul that is transcended from the material world, why does physical and chemical inputs on the brain have the power to very drastically affect a person’s personality and memories?

I’m not trying to deboonk with anything. I would like to believe in something like the soul, but I find it difficult to reconcile both concepts.

My personal excuse is that maybe the brain is like an egg or a womb of the soul so what ever physical affect damages the brain while a person is alive it causes an effect on the soul too before it leaves it the body after death. However it can’t be both falsified, nor verified.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33458363
You could essentially boil down the soul to conscious mind, not brain mind you. The soul is something that exists on the mental plane and not the material. Trying to save your soul and whatnot is essentially trying to hold on to your mind after death. immortality essentially. God is also just a conscious mind that created everything through his limitless imagination you could say. The material and the physical still exist mind you though it's a parallel to the mental and is still influenced by it through platonic forms and whatnot. Our own consciousness is much like a dream and it's possible our own reality is also a dream of the creator this is where simulation theory also kind of comes in

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33458363
It sounds like you're still assuming the material exists in both situations.
Either that it's material only, or material + immaterial.
But have you considered that it's _only_ immaterial? That is to say only soul/consciousness/higher-self.

>why does physical and chemical inputs on the brain have the power to very drastically affect a person’s personality and memories?
From my point of view there is no brain. And what you call the physical and chemical processes that occur therein are just appearances in consciousness.

Think about it this way. IF you claim you're just a brain receiving "inputs" then you've never seen the real world... Right? It would be an undeniable fact that 100% of your knowledge is a re-creation of an alleged "real world" that exists somewhere, but you've never seen it.
If you physically see a brain then that "brain" is a re-creation inside your head of a "real brain" that you assume exists, but it's not the one you're seeing.

This is why the scientific view suffers from a lack of ability to explain "realness". Because your entire reality as you know it is, according to your own theory, is a re-creation of what's "real".
So then why is it surprising to discover that you can never prove if an object you see is "real" or "simulated"? It's a core aspect of the theory itself.
In truth what this reveals is a kind of denial that most people have. Including scientists. Their own theories tell them they've never seen the "real world" but they want to go on assuming that it is, and claiming that the thing which informed them about that world in the first place (consciousness) is the illusion.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Hello /x/,
I don't usually post here but what just happened to me was a bit strange. For my privacy, however, and to keep some confidentiality, I wont name any names or be too specific about things but please just know that everything I write here is very much real.

OK, some bg first: I'm your typical middle-class WASP. Grew up in a rural suburb and lived a comfortable and idyllic life as a child. Read a lot and was pretty nerdy in my youth (still am of course), but in particular I found myself gravitating towards math and especially geometry (partly, I think, because my father was an architect and partly because my visual sense of pleasure is acute). The beauty of geometry is unsurpassed for me and the pleasure of completing a geometrical proof or construction is one of the most satisfying things in the world (as I'm sure some of you are aware).
Geometry has fascinated me as far back as I can remember but the real turning point for me was when, on my 8th birthday, I was gifted a leather-bound copy of Euclid's elements by my papa (along with a lego set and some toy cars). I can't tell you how many hours I spent reading that and bothering my dad over it (it was very fun, I encourage you guys to do the same with your kids).

Anyway, the point is I was privileged and had parents who encouraged me to get to where I am now: a math undergraduate at "Ivy League University".

Curiously though, a professor of mine espied me having lunch alone one day and came over to sit with me. This made me very uncomfortable for two reasons: first, I didn't want company (much less from some professor) and second, I was drawing some geometrical construction (which is something that has addicted me much since I was a child) and I was embarrassed to be seen doing math like that around my professor (silly I guess but I'm very self conscious).
The odd thing was that he just got close to me and said
>nice construction, I guess you're a Ganymede initiate, huh? you are [my father]'s boy right?

-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it

-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option

You may think this is obvious, but I see people dismissing these things as inconsequential all the time. When someone has a dream, and someone else says 'it wasn't real', what they are really saying is that it was inconsequential, which is not true in the slightest, even though this is what they actually seem to believe.
>But then the world "real" has no meaning
Yes. It really doesn't in the way it is used now, but it would if it was simply used to mean "not present in our physical world" or something of the sort, instead of being charged with that extra meaning of "it shouldn't even affect you at all". It's bizarre, because most people wouldn't even deny that a good fiction book could change the way you look at things, but for some reason they can't take that to its logical conclusion.
